content.raw: Quick comment about the wired troughput during interprocess communication over the wire. The approximate maximum throughput for TCP over Gigabit Ethernet should be around 120MB/s . That's probably why the curve saturates at that point.
content.html: Quick comment about the wired troughput during interprocess communication over the wire. The approximate maximum throughput for TCP over Gigabit Ethernet should be around 120MB/s . That's probably why the curve saturates at that point.

content.raw: Agreed. We approached the theoretical limit of TCP over gigabit ethernet.
content.html: Agreed. We approached the theoretical limit of TCP over gigabit ethernet.

content.raw:
The main issue that I see after thinking on this during some time is the extra Ignition Common dependency. I see two main problems:

* Currently, Ignition Common doesn't build on Windows. This will affect the Ignition Transport CI because all Windows builds won't work until we fix the Ignition Common CI. The current plan is to merge the initial Ignition CMake [PR](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-cmake/pull-requests/1), and then, merge the CMakeRefactor [PR](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-common/pull-requests/69) in Ignition Common. In my opinion, this is just an issue that will delay the merge of this pull request a little bit, but it's not a big deal if Ignition Common is fixed.

* The main concern that I have is the size of Ignition Common in terms of dependencies. Here is some data:
  * [Recursive list of dependencies on Ignition Transport 3.x.x](https://bitbucket.org/snippets/osrf/9jaEzk/ignition-transport-3xx-recursive)
  * [Recursive list of dependencies on Ignition Common 0.x.x](https://bitbucket.org/snippets/osrf/zj5Ex5/ignition-common-0xx-recursive-dependencies)
  * [Diff](https://bitbucket.org/snippets/osrf/9jaERX/dependencies-diff-ignition-transport-3xx)

  For the record, I created the list with:
  
```
#!c++

apt-rdepends libignition-transport-dev | grep Depends | cut -d" " -f4 | sort | uniq > /tmp/transport_deps
apt-rdepends libignition-common-dev | grep Depends | cut -d" " -f4 | sort | uniq > /tmp/common_deps
cat /tmp/transport_deps /tmp/common_deps | sort | uniq -u > diff_deps
grep -Fvxf /tmp/transport_deps /tmp/diff_deps > /tmp/diff
```

I'm not 100% convinced that the need of `common::WorkerPool` justifies to pull all these extra dependencies. Note, that some of the dependencies will already exist in a basic installation, but I think is arguable the need to pull audio and video dependencies (for example) into Ignition Transport. [This issue](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-common/issues/14) captures more details about it.

Here are a few proposals:

* Copy the `WorkerPool` class into Ignition Transport.
* Split `Ignition Common` into multiple libraries. I'd like to see `Ignition Common` as a pretty lightweight library focused in real common features that can be implemented with just a few dependencies. I'm aware that this can take a bit of discussion, so I'm leaning towards the other options until we have a clear idea of the `Ignition Common` direction. I think this is the right way to go, but will block this PR for some time.
* Maybe there's an easy way to use `std::async` instead of a `WorkerPool`. Just an idea, I haven't thought much about it.

The main issue that I see after thinking on this during some time is the extra Ignition Common dependency. I see two main problems:

  • Currently, Ignition Common doesn't build on Windows. This will affect the Ignition Transport CI because all Windows builds won't work until we fix the Ignition Common CI. The current plan is to merge the initial Ignition CMake PR, and then, merge the CMakeRefactor PR in Ignition Common. In my opinion, this is just an issue that will delay the merge of this pull request a little bit, but it's not a big deal if Ignition Common is fixed.

  • The main concern that I have is the size of Ignition Common in terms of dependencies. Here is some data:

  • Recursive list of dependencies on Ignition Transport 3.x.x
  • Recursive list of dependencies on Ignition Common 0.x.x
  • Diff

For the record, I created the list with:

apt-rdepends libignition-transport-dev | grep Depends | cut -d" " -f4 | sort | uniq > /tmp/transport_deps
apt-rdepends libignition-common-dev | grep Depends | cut -d" " -f4 | sort | uniq > /tmp/common_deps
cat /tmp/transport_deps /tmp/common_deps | sort | uniq -u > diff_deps
grep -Fvxf /tmp/transport_deps /tmp/diff_deps > /tmp/diff

I'm not 100% convinced that the need of common::WorkerPool justifies to pull all these extra dependencies. Note, that some of the dependencies will already exist in a basic installation, but I think is arguable the need to pull audio and video dependencies (for example) into Ignition Transport. This issue captures more details about it.

Here are a few proposals:

  • Copy the WorkerPool class into Ignition Transport.
  • Split Ignition Common into multiple libraries. I'd like to see Ignition Common as a pretty lightweight library focused in real common features that can be implemented with just a few dependencies. I'm aware that this can take a bit of discussion, so I'm leaning towards the other options until we have a clear idea of the Ignition Common direction. I think this is the right way to go, but will block this PR for some time.
  • Maybe there's an easy way to use std::async instead of a WorkerPool. Just an idea, I haven't thought much about it.

content.raw:
I'll try the std::async approach.

I agree with trying to reduce dependencies, but it is a balance. The goal of Ignition is to have as few libraries as possible, with plugins playing a larger role.

content.raw:
Based on a different conversation, it seems that eventually we should be able to depend on `Ignition Common` without having to install all extra dependencies. How about if we copy the `WorkerPool` class in `Ignition Transport` until we depend on `Ignition Common`. I see a few advantages:

* The behavior won't change when we replace the `WorkerPool` from `Ignition Common` (hopefully soon).
* I haven't tested but it might be a bit overkill to create and destroy a thread every time that we publish a message for every destination node (located in the same process).
content.html:
Based on a different conversation, it seems that eventually we should be able to depend on Ignition Common without having to install all extra dependencies. How about if we copy the WorkerPool class in Ignition Transport until we depend on Ignition Common. I see a few advantages:

  • The behavior won't change when we replace the WorkerPool from Ignition Common (hopefully soon).
  • I haven't tested but it might be a bit overkill to create and destroy a thread every time that we publish a message for every destination node (located in the same process).

content.raw: Local workerpool has been added.
content.html: Local workerpool has been added.

content.raw: All calls to `<condition_variable>.wait(lk)` should be changed to `<condition_variable>.wait(lk, bool_expression)` to avoid spurious wakeups. See [here](http://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/thread/condition_variable/wait).
content.html: All calls to <condition_variable>.wait(lk) should be changed to <condition_variable>.wait(lk, bool_expression) to avoid spurious wakeups. See here.

I can't reproduce the flat intraprocess latency results with ce37a0e8982b

![latency-20171030-ce37a0e8982b Intraprocess-all.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/og7EBq/images/2241567057-latency-20171030-ce37a0e8982b_Intraprocess-all.png)

content.raw:
I can confirm that you are seeing the correct data. The original plots were made with code that avoided a message copy. The downside was that intraprocess subscribers blocked the publisher. `Node.cc` was changed so that intraprocess subscribers receive their callbacks asynchronously. In order to make that work, the message had to be copied.

We will address this performance issue in a future pull request by offering different publish API calls that support no-copy.
content.html:
I can confirm that you are seeing the correct data. The original plots were made with code that avoided a message copy. The downside was that intraprocess subscribers blocked the publisher. Node.cc was changed so that intraprocess subscribers receive their callbacks asynchronously. In order to make that work, the message had to be copied.

We will address this performance issue in a future pull request by offering different publish API calls that support no-copy.

content.raw: I'll also update the benchmark data sets in this PR to match the current code.
content.html: I'll also update the benchmark data sets in this PR to match the current code.

content.raw:
I would suggest moving this code to the constructor, to match a RAII pattern.

Or if there's a reason to have an `Init()` function (e.g. we want to re-run the `PubTester` from scratch without destructing and reconstructing the `PubTester` object), then we should at least call `this->Init()` from the constructor so that it's ready to be used right away.
content.html:
I would suggest moving this code to the constructor, to match a RAII pattern.

Or if there's a reason to have an Init() function (e.g. we want to re-run the PubTester from scratch without destructing and reconstructing the PubTester object), then we should at least call this->Init() from the constructor so that it's ready to be used right away.

content.raw: What is the concrete benefit of moving this code?
content.html: What is the concrete benefit of moving this code?

content.raw:
If we ever have cause to change the implementation of this example, we won't have to remember that the object is uninitialized after construction.

I don't mind encapsulating this work in the `Init()` function, but we should at least call `this->Init()` from the constructor to avoid having uninitialized objects.
content.html:
If we ever have cause to change the implementation of this example, we won't have to remember that the object is uninitialized after construction.

I don't mind encapsulating this work in the Init() function, but we should at least call this->Init() from the constructor to avoid having uninitialized objects.

content.raw: +1 to not having a separate `Init` step unless there is a use for an uninitialized object.
content.html: +1 to not having a separate Init step unless there is a use for an uninitialized object.

content.raw: Take a look at the main function.
content.html: Take a look at the main function.

content.raw:
I don't see anything in the main function to motivate a separation of the construction and initialization. The `Init()` function does not use any member variables, so those don't need to be set before it gets called (and even if it were the case that they did, that would imply that the values for those variables should be constructor arguments).

Edit: To clarify, when I say "does not use any member variables", I mean it does not consume any variables that are expected to already have been set. Obviously it does set some variables.
content.html:
I don't see anything in the main function to motivate a separation of the construction and initialization. The Init() function does not use any member variables, so those don't need to be set before it gets called (and even if it were the case that they did, that would imply that the values for those variables should be constructor arguments).

Edit: To clarify, when I say "does not use any member variables", I mean it does not consume any variables that are expected to already have been set. Obviously it does set some variables.

content.raw: Sorry, the key bit is that I wanted Init to be called after `ReplyTester` had been created. There was a reason I had done this, but I can't remember it now. I'm testing both versions in case I'm missing something.
content.html: Sorry, the key bit is that I wanted Init to be called after ReplyTester had been created. There was a reason I had done this, but I can't remember it now. I'm testing both versions in case I'm missing something.

content.raw:
It's starting to come back to me. I wanted topics to be created based on command line flags, but I also need a globally scoped object to properly handle sigints. So, I needed an Init function.

For example, `Init` is not called with the `-r` option.

I guess I could use a `PubTester` pointer, and construct it when needed.
content.html:
It's starting to come back to me. I wanted topics to be created based on command line flags, but I also need a globally scoped object to properly handle sigints. So, I needed an Init function.

For example, Init is not called with the -r option.

I guess I could use a PubTester pointer, and construct it when needed.

content.raw:
One plausible explanation might be that as soon as we call `Init()` and subscribe to the topics, the `PubTester` will be getting put to work. By that point, we might already need to have provided the member variables with values.

Since `gPubTester` is a global variable,  we won't have very good control over the flow of information.

I suppose it boils down to the inherent ugliness of global variables. Since this is just an example which we aren't likely to touch on much, I won't try to work out a global variable-less implementation.
content.html:
One plausible explanation might be that as soon as we call Init() and subscribe to the topics, the PubTester will be getting put to work. By that point, we might already need to have provided the member variables with values.

Since gPubTester is a global variable, we won't have very good control over the flow of information.

I suppose it boils down to the inherent ugliness of global variables. Since this is just an example which we aren't likely to touch on much, I won't try to work out a global variable-less implementation.

content.raw: It starts to get ugly if I try to use a pointer. I'm inclined to leave it alone.
content.html: It starts to get ugly if I try to use a pointer. I'm inclined to leave it alone.

content.raw: If we expect `_stream` to always be a valid object (and not a `nullptr`) we should consider accepting it by reference instead of by pointer. Or at least we should handle the case of `_stream == nullptr`.
content.html: If we expect _stream to always be a valid object (and not a nullptr) we should consider accepting it by reference instead of by pointer. Or at least we should handle the case of _stream == nullptr.

content.raw: This is a private function in an example program. Passing a pointer should be fine.
content.html: This is a private function in an example program. Passing a pointer should be fine.

content.raw:
Now I think I understand what happened. Pull request #247 and pull request #250 were merged into default but never into `ign-transport4`. This branch as well as the branch for pull request #251 merged in those changes from default. We're targeting this branch at `ign-transport4`, even though `ign-transport4` never got those changes from default.

While it's a little bit convoluted, I suppose it's not really an issue. Those changes can be thought of as already approved.
content.html:
Now I think I understand what happened. Pull request #247 and pull request #250 were merged into default but never into ign-transport4. This branch as well as the branch for pull request #251 merged in those changes from default. We're targeting this branch at ign-transport4, even though ign-transport4 never got those changes from default.

While it's a little bit convoluted, I suppose it's not really an issue. Those changes can be thought of as already approved.
